text: I've been writing all of my styling in a local dev folder that compiles CSS into a folder that is being watched by the local dev beta and automatically uploaded to the server. I find that it's a much better option that writing inside of the design manager if you're comfortable with command line tools for development.
Info on the local dev beta here: <https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/tools/local-development>

There's a pretty good and (at least currently) actively developed local development tooling here with Sass compiling, JS compiling, live reloading, minification, etc... built by someone who is unaffiliated with HubSpot: <https://github.com/paulca55/HubSpot-local-development#changelog>
Autoprefixing is included in that set up

I’m struggling with modifying the 3rd level menu to be mega menulike mentioned here <https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/CMS-Development/Multi-column-navigation-dropdown/td-p/29664>

chasing classes is really proving to be difficult with all of the build in classes and I don’t have an option to add a class to a menu item.

Ohhh man - Megamenus and HubSpot are notoriously tricky… I am in the tail end of a pretty complex one now. What made the process the easiest for myself is actually making use of the `menu()` function and building out everything myself with some nested for loops to create the structure.

It works really well and arguably takes equal if not a little less time than digging through all of the default classes and wrappers and what not that HubSpot uses when creating menus. Not to mention it gets rid of all of the overriding work you will need to do.

But it sounds like youre pretty far in the process already and are just trying to style the third level? What issues are you running into?
Yeah, I've mostly built custom modules when building these myself as I find it tricky to work with the default menu modules.
